columns.text: The exercise will require us to prepare a Pro-forma balance sheet and compute the EFN of Heir Jordan Corporation.

### Let's first provide the given data in the problem.

* The sales are expected to increase by 15%.
* No new external debt or equity financing.
* The payout ratio is constant.
* Declared dividends are $2,400.00.
* Addition to the retained earnings is $4,386.00.
* Accounts payable vary with sales.

### Last, provide the given balance sheet.

$$
\begin{array}{c}
\textbf{Cardinal, Inc.}\\
\text{Balance Sheet}
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lrlr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}&\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\textbf{Current Assets}&&\textbf{Current Liabilities}\\

\text{Cash}&\$2,950.00&\text{Accounts Payable}&\$2,400.00\\

\text{Acc Receivable}&4,100.00&\text{Notes Payable}&\underline{5,400.00}\\

\text{Inventory}&\underline{6,400.00}&\text{Total}&\$7,800.00\\
\text{Total}&\$13,450.00&\text{Long Term Debt}&28,000.00\\
\textbf{Fixed Assets}\\
\text{Plant \& Equip't}&41,300.00&\textbf{Owner's Equity}\\
&&\text{Common \& Paid In Cap}&15,000.00\\
&\underline{\text{------------}}&\text{Retained Earnings}&\underline{3,950.00}\\
\textbf{Total Assets}&\underline{\underline{\$54,750.00}}&\textbf{Total Liab \&  Equity}&\underline{\underline{\$54,750.00}}


\end{array}
$$

## Requirement.

Compute the EFN and prepare a Pro-forma balance sheet.

### Compute the projected sales for next year.

The projected sales are computed by multiplying the expected sales growth with the current sales. The sales will increase by 15%.

The formula and computation are as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Projected Sales}&= \text{Sales Growth} \times \text{Current Year Sales}\\[15pt]
&= 115\% \times \$49,000.00\\[15pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{\$56,350.00}}

\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the projected sales for next year are **$56,350.00**.

### Compute the percentage share of the cost of sales from the sales.

Computation of the percentage share of the cost of sales is needed to compute the projected cost of sales.


$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Percentage of Cost of Sales from Sales}&= \dfrac{ \text{Cost of Sales}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$40,300.00}{\$49,000.00}\\[15pt]

&= 0.8225 \times 100\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{\textbf{82.25\%}}

\end{aligned}
$$


Therefore, the percentage of the cost of sales from sales is **82.25%**.

### Compute the taxable income.

The projected taxable income will be used in calculating the business tax.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Sales}&\$56,350.00\\
\text{Cost of Sales}&\underline{46,347.88}\\
\text{Taxable Income}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$10,002.12}}}\\

\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the taxable income is **$10,002.12**.

### Compute the projected net income using the Pro-forma Income statement.

After computing the projected cost of sales and business tax, we can now calculate the projected net income.

The calculation is as follows.

$$
\begin{array}{c}
\textbf{Heir Jordan Corp.}\\
\text{Pro Forma}\\
\text{Income Statement}
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Sales}&\$56,350.00\\
\text{Cost of Sales}&\underline{43,347.88}\\
\text{Taxable Income}&10,002.12\\
\text{Taxes(22\%)}&\underline{2,200.47}\\
\textbf{Net Income}&\underline{\underline{\$7,801.65}}

\end{array}
$$


Therefore, the net income is **$7,801.65**.

### Compute the payout ratio.

The projected dividend is calculated by multiplying the net income with the payout ratio. The problem is silent to the payout ratio. Therefore, we will compute the payout ratio.
 
The formula and calculation are as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Payout Ratio}&= \dfrac{ \text{Declared Dividends}}{\text{Net Income}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$2,400.00}{\$6,786.00}\\[15pt]

&= 0.3537 \times 100\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{\textbf{35.37\%}}

\end{aligned}
$$
Therefore, the payout ratio is **35.37%**.

### Compute the addition to the retained earnings.

The addition to the retained earnings is calculated by deducting the projected dividend from the projected net income.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Net Income}&\$7,801.65\\
\text{Less: Projected Dividends}&\underline{(2,759.44)}\\
\text{Addition to the Retained Earnings}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$5,042.21}}}\\
\end{array}
$$


Therefore, the addition to the retained earnings is **$5,042.21**.

### Compute the new balance of the retained earnings.

The new balance of the retained earnings is calculated by adding the beginning balance and the retained earnings from the projected net income.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Retained Earnings, Beg Bal}&\$3,950.00\\
\text{Addition to the Retained Earnings}&\underline{5,042.21}\\
\text{Projected  Retained Earnings}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$8,992.21}}}\\
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the projected retained earnings are **$8,992.21**.

### In summary, the increase in various balance sheet accounts is presented as follows.

These are the accounts that vary with the increase in sales.


|	Accounts	|	Original Amount	|	Projected Amount	|	Increase by	|
|--		|--:		|--:		|--:		|
|	Cash	|	$2,950.00 	|	$3,392.50 	|	$442.50 	|
|	Accounts Receivable	|	$4,100.00 	|	$4,715.00 	|	$615.00 	|
|	Inventory	|	$6,400.00 	|	$7,360.00 	|	$960.00 	|
|	Net Plant Equipment	|	$41,300.00 	|	$47,495.00 	|	$6,195.00 	|
|	Accounts Payable	|	$2,400.00 	|	$2,760.00 	|	$360.00 	|

### Compute the total assets.

After the proportional increase, the total assets will change based on the increase.
$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Cash}&\$3,392.50\\
\text{Accounts Receivable}&4,715.00\\
\text{Inventory}&7,360.00\\
\text{Net Plant Equipment}&\underline{47,495.00}\\
\textbf{Total Assests}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$62,962.50}}}

\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the total assets are **$62,962.50**.

### Compute the EFN (external financing needed).

Assets should equal the sum of the liabilities and owner's equity. To compute the EFN, we will deduct the liabilities and owner's equity from the projected asset.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\textbf{Total Assets}&\$62,962.50\\
\textbf{Less:}\\
\hspace{5pt}\text{Accounts Payable}&2,760.00\\

\hspace{5pt}\text{Notes Payable}&5,400.00\\

\hspace{5pt}\text{Long Term Debt}&28,000.00\\

\hspace{5pt}\text{Common Stock \& Paid in Cap}&15,000.00\\

\hspace{5pt}\text{Retained Earnings}&\underline{8,992.21}\\

\textbf{EFN}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$2,810.29}}}

\end{array}
$$


Therefore, the EFN (external financing needed) is **$2,810.29**.

Based on the calculation of the EFN, the company will require an additional $2.810.29 external financing. However, the problem specifies that the company should not require new external debt or equity financing. We are to allocate the portion to the current and noncurrent liabilities.

The total current assets increased by $2,017.50 (cash, accounts receivable, and inventory), while the total liabilities increased only by $360, making the working capital not balanced. The difference will be attributable to the notes payable account to keep the working capital balance.


The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Increase in Assets}&\$2,017.50\\
\text{Less: Increase in Accounts Payable}&\underline{(360.00)}\\
\text{Attributable to Notes Payable}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$1,657.50}}}\\
\end{array}
$$


Therefore, the projected increase for Notes Payable will be **$1,657.50**.

### Compute the projected notes payable.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Notes Payable}&\$5,400.00\\
\text{Increase in Notes Payable}&\underline{1,657.50}\\
\text{Attributable to Notes Payable}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$7,057.50}}}\\
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the projected notes payable is **$7,057.50**.

### Compute the balance of the EFN (external financing needed).

The balance is calculated by deducting the possible increase to Notes Payable.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{EFN}&\$2,810.29\\
\text{Less: Increase in Notes Payable}&\underline{(1,657.50)}\\
\text{EFN, Balance}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$1,152.79}}}\\
\end{array}
$$
The balance of the EFN is **$1,152.79.**

### Compute the projected long-term debt due to the EFN.

The balance of the EFN would come from the long-term debt as an additional borrowing.

The projected long-term debt is calculated as follows.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\text{Long-Term Debt}&\$28,000.00\\
\text{EFN attributable to long-term debt}&\underline{1,152.79}\\
\text{Projected Long-Term debt}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$29,152.79}}}\\
\end{array}
$$

The projected long-term debit is **$29,152.79.**

### Prepare the Pro-forma balance sheet.


$$
\begin{array}{c}
\textbf{Cardinal, Inc.}\\
\text{Pro Forma}\\

\text{Balance Sheet}
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lrlr}
\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}&\textbf{Description}&\underline{\textbf{Amount}}\\[10pt]
\textbf{Current Assets}&&\textbf{Current Liabilities}\\

\text{Cash}&\$3,392.50&\text{Accounts Payable}&\$2,760.00\\

\text{Acc Receivable}&4,715.00&\text{Notes Payable}&\underline{7,057.50}\\

\text{Inventory}&\underline{7,360.00}&\text{Total}&\$9,817.50\\
\text{Total}&\$15,467.50&\text{Long Term Debt}&29,152.79\\
\textbf{Fixed Assets}\\
\text{Plant \& Equip't}&47,495.00&\textbf{Owner's Equity}\\
&&\text{Common \& Paid In Cap}&15,000.00\\
&\underline{\text{------------}}&\text{Retained Earnings}&\underline{8,992.21}\\
\textbf{Total Assets}&\underline{\underline{\$62,962.50}}&\textbf{Total Liab \&  Equity}&\underline{\underline{\$62,962.50}}


\end{array}
$$
In this exercise, we are to prepare the pro forma balance sheet of the company based on the information on the previous exercise.

## Pro Forma Statements
\
Pro Forma statements include a forecasted balance sheet, an income statement, and a statement of cash flows. These financial statements are necessary for the determination of the summary of projected events in the succeeding years of operation of the firm.
\
The pro forma statements are considered outputs of the financial plan. The management would estimate the projected and would then produce the pro forma statements.

The information in exercise 9 is as follows:
 

<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Income Statement||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Sales|\$49,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Cost|\$40,300|
|$\hspace{30pt}$Taxable Income|\$8,700|
|$\hspace{30pt}$Tax Expenses (22\%)|\$1,914|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Net Income|\$6,786|
|Dividends|\$2,400|
|Addition to Retained Earnings|\$4,386|

Now, let us prepare the pro forma income statement:
 
$$\textbf{Pro Forma}\\
\textbf{Income Statement}$$

$$\begin{array}{l r}
\text{Sales}&{\$56,350}\\
\text{Cost}&\underline{46,207}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Taxable Income}&{\$10,143}\\
\hspace{10pt}\text{Taxes}&\underline{2,231.46}\\
\hspace{20pt}\textbf{Net Income}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$}\textbf{7,911.54}}}\\
\end{array}$$

## Percentage of Sales Approach
\
The percentage of sales approach is a financial planning model in which the concept is to separate the accounts in the income statement and in the balance sheet into two sections- one which is directly affected by sales and the other which does not.
\
Through the sales forecast, the amount of the necessary funding is determined that will support the estimated sales of the company.

Now, let us prepare the balance sheet using the following given:
 

<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Assets||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Cash|\$2,950|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Accounts Receivable|\$4,100|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Inventory|\$6,400|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Net Plant and Equipment|\$41,300|
|Liabilities and Owners' Equity||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Accounts Payable|\$2,400|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Notes Payable|\$5,400|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Long-term Debt|\$28,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Common Stock and Paid-in Surplus|\$15,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Retained Earnings|\$3,950|

The table in the succeding step indicates a change in the accounts in the balance sheet. This amount is derived at by deducting the current amounts in the balance sheet from the projected amounts to determine the difference/ changes in the said amounts.

Based on the partial balance sheet, the company requires external financing amounting to \$2,248.50. Since the problem indicates that the company should not require new external debt or equity financing, we are to allocate the amount on the current and non-current liabilities of the company.
The remaining external financing needed would come from the long-term debt as an additional borrowing.
In this task, we are asked to prepare a pro forma balance sheet that includes EFN (External Finance Needed) using the information provided.

Pro forma statements, or pro forms for short, are a type of financial statement. The financial statements are the format that we use to summarize the many events that are predicted to take place in the future. When creating a financial plan, it is important to include the balance sheet, income statement, and statement of cash flows expected while constructing a financial plan.

EFN (External Finance Needed ) is the difference between what a company can raise from its own earnings and savings and the entire amount of capital necessary to accomplish the planned project or transaction. This overview of external finance is obtained from pro forma financial statements that forecast the financial situation of the firm, such as a pro forma income statement and balance sheet, as well as other financial documents.

We know from the previous task that the company predicted sales growth of 15%. It implies that each item on the balance sheet will increase by 15%. Each item will be calculated separately, and the results will be shown in a table of pro forma statements.

The universal formula we will use to calculate the 15% increase will be:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{X}_{\text{projected}}=(\text{X}_{\text{current}} \cdot 15\%) + \text{X}_{\text{current}}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

X$_{\text{projected}}$ = Projected amount after an increase of 15%

X$_{\text{current}}$= Current amount before an increase of 15%

To determine the amount of projected taxable income, we will deduct projected costs from projected sales such as:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PTI}=\text{PS}-\text{PC}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PTI = Projected Taxable Income

PS = Projected Sales

PC = Projected Costs

We get the amount of projected taxes we will multiply taxes (22%) by projected taxable income in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PT}=\text{PTI}\cdot 22\%
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PT = Projected Taxes

PTI = Projected Taxable Income

To calculate the amount of projected net income, we will deduct projected costs and projected taxes from projected sales.

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PNI}=\text{PS}-\text{PC}-\text{PT}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PNI = Projected Net Income

PS = Projected Sales

PC = Projected Costs

PT = Projected Taxes

To determine projected dividends, we recall that the payout ratio is constant, so we will calculated it by dividing the dividends by the net income of the current period and multiplying the obtained result by the projected net income.

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PD}=\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{NI}}\cdot\text{PNI}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PD = Projected Dividend

D = Dividend

NI = Net Income

PNI = Projected Net Income

The value of projected addition to retained earnings can be calculated by subtracting predicted net income and the amount of dividend that is expected to be paid as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PARE}=\text{PNI}-\text{PD}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PARE = Projected Addition to Retained Earnings

PNI = Projected Net Income

PD = Projected Dividend

The value of cumulative retained earnings can be computed as the sum of current addition retained earnings and projected addition retained earnings as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{CRE}=\text{ARE}+\text{PARE}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

CRE =  Cumulative Retained Earnings

ARE = Addition Retained Earnings 

PARE = Projected Addition Retained Earnings

The value of total assets after increase is calculated as follows:
$$\begin{align*}
\text{TA}=\text{PCA}+\text{PAR}+\text{PI}+\text{PNPE}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

TA = Total Assets

PCA = Projected Cash

PAR = Projected  Accounts Receivable

PI = Projected Inventory 

PNPE = Projected  Net Plant and Equipment

The value of total liabilities and equity after increase is calculated as follows:
$$\begin{align*}
\text{TLE}=\text{PAP}+\text{NP}+\text{LTD}+\text{CS}+\text{CRE}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

TLE = Total Liabilities and Equity

PAP = Projected Accounts Payable

NP = Notes Payable

LTD = Long-Term Debt

CS = Common Stock

CRE = Cumulative Retained Earnings

The value of external financing needed after increase is the difference total amount of assets and the total liabilities and equity as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{EFN}=\text{TA}-\text{TLE}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

EFN = External Financing Needed

TA = Total Assets

TLE = Total Liabilities and Equity

First step is to calculate the value of projected sales (PS) after increase we will use the equation from step 4. To do that, we will multiply the amount of current sales (S) by 0.15. Then the result will be added to the quantity of current sales.

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PS}&=(\text{S} \cdot 15\%) + \text{S}\\[5pt]
&=(\$53,000 \cdot 0.15) +\$53,000\\[5pt]
&=\$7,950+\$53,000\\[5pt]
&=\$60,950
\end{align*}$$

The projected sales are $60,950.

Then to calculate the value of projected costs (PC) after increase we will use the equation from step 4 as the same way as shown above. We will multiply the amount of current costs (C) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current costs.

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PC}&=(\text{C} \cdot 15\%) + \text{C}\\[5pt]
&=(\$40,900 \cdot 0.15) +\$40,900\\[5pt]
&=\$6,135+\$40,900\\[5pt]
&=\$47,035
\end{align*}$$

The projected costs are $47,035.

The next step is to calculate projected taxable income using the equation from step 5 as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PTI}&=\text{PS}-\text{PC}\\[5pt]
&=\$60,950-\$47,035\\[5pt]
&=\$13,915
\end{align*}$$

The projected taxable income is $13,915.

To calculate the value of projected taxes we will use the equation from step 6 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PT}&=\text{PTI}\cdot 22\%\\[5pt]
&=\$14,520\cdot 0.22\\[5pt]
&=\$3,194.4
\end{align*}$$

The projected taxes are $3,194.4.

To calculate the value of projected net income we will use the equation from step 7 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PNI}&=\text{PS}-\text{PC}-\text{PT}\\[5pt]
&=\$60,950-\$47,035-\$3,194.4\\[5pt]
&=\$10,720.6
\end{align*}$$

The projected net income is $10,720.6.

Then, to calculate the value of projected net income we will use the equation from step 8 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PD}&=\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{NI}}\cdot\text{PNI}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\$3,500}{\$ 9,438}\cdot\$10,720.6\\[10pt]
&=\$3,975.6
\end{align*}$$

The projected dividend is $3,975.6.

To calculate the value of projected addition to retained earnings we will use the equation from step 9 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PARE}&=\text{PNI}-\text{PD}\\[5pt]
&=\$10,720.6-\$3,975.6\\[5pt]
&=\$6,745
\end{align*}$$

The projected addition to retained earnings is $6,745.

To compute the value of cumulative retained earnings we will use the equation from step 10 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{CRE}&=\text{ARE}+\text{PARE}\\[5pt]
&=\$5,938+\$6,745\\[5pt]
&=\$12,683
\end{align*}$$

The cumulative retained earnings are $12,683.

Then to calculate the value of projected cash (PCA) after increase we will use the equation from step 4 as the same way as shown above. We will multiply the amount of current cash (CA) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current cash as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PCA}&=(\text{CA} \cdot 15\%) + \text{CA}\\[5pt]
&=(\$ 3,140 \cdot 0.15) +\$ 3,140\\[5pt]
&=\$471+\$3,140\\[5pt]
&=\$3,611
\end{align*}$$

The projected cash is $3,611.

In the same way we will use the equation from step 4 to calculate the value of projected accounts receivable (PAR) by multiplying the amount of current accounts receivable (AR) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current accounts receivable as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PAR}&=(\text{AR} \cdot 15\%) + \text{AR}\\[5pt]
&=(\$ 4,200 \cdot 0.15) +\$ 4,200\\[5pt]
&=\$630+\$4,200\\[5pt]
&=\$4,830
\end{align*}$$

The projected accounts receivable is $4,830

As above that we will use the equation from step 4 to calculate the value of projected inventory (PI) by multiplying the amount of current inventory (I) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current inventory as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PI}&=(\text{I} \cdot 15\%) + \text{I}\\[5pt]
&=(\$ 6,500 \cdot 0.15) +\$ 6,500\\[5pt]
&=\$975+\$6,500\\[5pt]
&=\$7,475
\end{align*}$$

The projected inventory is $7,475

In the same way we will use the equation from step 4 to calculate the value of projected net plant and equipment (PNPE) by multiplying the amount of current net plant and equipment (NPE) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current net plant and equipment as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PNPE}&=(\text{NPE} \cdot 15\%) + \text{NPE}\\[5pt]
&=(\$43,200 \cdot 0.15) +\$43,200\\[5pt]
&=\$6,480+\$43,200\\[5pt]
&=\$49,680
\end{align*}$$

The projected net plant and equipment is $49,680.

The projected accounts payable (PAP) will be calculated using formula 4 by  multiplying the amount of current accounts payable (AP) by 0.15, then the result will be added to the quantity of current accounts payable as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PAP}&=(\text{AP} \cdot 15\%) + \text{AP}\\[5pt]
&=(\$2,600 \cdot 0.15) +\$2,600\\[5pt]
&=\$390+\$2,600\\[5pt]
&=\$2,990
\end{align*}$$

The projected accounts payable is $2,990

To determine the amount of total assets we will use the equation from step 11 as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{TA}&=\text{PCA}+\text{PAR}+\text{PI}+\text{PNPE}\\[5pt]
&=\$3,611+\$4,830+\$7,475+\$49,680\\[5pt]
&=\$65,596
\end{align*}$$

The amount of total assets is $65,596.

To compute the amount of total liabilities and equity we will use the equation from step 12 as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{TLE}&=\text{PAP}+\text{NP}+\text{LTD}+\text{CS}+\text{CRE}\\[5pt]
&=\$2,990+\$5,700+\$28,000+\$5,000+\$12,683\\[5pt]
&=\$54,373
\end{align*}$$

The amount of total liabilities and equity is $54,373.

After calculating all the essential elements for the balance sheet, we can now determine the value of the external financing needed using the equation from step 13 as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{EFN}&=\text{TA}-\text{TLE}\\[5pt]
&=\$65,596-\$54,373\\[5pt]
&=\$11,223
\end{align*}$$

In conclusion, the amount of external finance needed with sales growth of 15% for Heir Jordan Corporation is $11,223.
